qas.question: What conclusion do most of Hume's followers disagree with?

answers.text: that belief in an external world is rationally unjustifiable

qas.question: What did Hume say can't be rationally justified?

answers.text: physical objects, properties, events (whatever is physical) are reducible to mental objects, properties, events

qas.question: What is subjective idealism closely related to?
What did John Stuart Mill say matter is?
When did DW Hamlin publish his essays?

plausible_answers.text: Hume's own principles implicitly contained the rational justification for such a belief

qas.question: Why did John Stuart Mill disagree with Hume?

context: Most of <b9_0>Hume's followers<b9_0/> have disagreed with his conclusion <a0_0>that <a1_0>belief in an external world<a1_0/> is rationally unjustifiable<a0_0/>, contending that <b7_0>Hume's own principles implicitly contained the rational justification for such a belief<b7_0/>, that is, beyond being content to let the issue rest on human instinct, custom and habit. According to an extreme empiricist theory known as phenomenalism, anticipated by the arguments of both <b5_0>Hume and George Berkeley<b5_0/>, a physical object is a kind of construction out of our experiences. <a3_0>Phenomenalism<a3_0/> is the view that <a2_0>physical objects, properties, events (whatever is physical) are reducible to mental objects, properties, events<a2_0/>. Ultimately, only mental objects, properties, events, exist — hence the closely related term subjective idealism. By the phenomenalistic line of thinking, to have a visual experience of a real physical thing is to have an experience of a certain kind of group of experiences. This type of set of experiences possesses a constancy and coherence that is lacking in the set of experiences of which hallucinations, for example, are a part. As John Stuart Mill put it in the <b6_0><b8_0>mid-19th century<b8_0/><b6_0/>, matter is <a4_0>the "permanent possibility of sensation"<a4_0/>. Mill's empiricism went a significant step beyond Hume in still another respect: in maintaining that induction is necessary for all meaningful knowledge including mathematics. As summarized by D.W. Hamlin:
